dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Informal and conversational, discussing current events.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, um, have you been following the ongoing... like, beef between Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey? It's really escalated, hasn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, um, have you been following the ongoing... like, beef between Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey? It's really escalated, hasn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The afternoon jousting added to a growing public spat between the two Internet moguls, both facing pressure to eliminate massive disinformation campaigns on their networks ahead of the 2020 general election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my gosh, absolutely. It's wild. Especially with, you know, the 2020 election looming. They're just constantly at odds, defending totally opposite views on some pretty big internet issues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my gosh, absolutely. It's wild. Especially with, you know, the twenty twenty election looming. They're just constantly at odds, defending totally opposite views on some pretty big internet issues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now the two billionaire tech founders are at odds over how to handle free speech and political advertising, defending opposite views of a heavily debated internet issue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And it really kicked off, uh, with the whole political advertising thing. I mean, Dorsey at Twitter was pretty vocal about this for a while, wasn't he?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And it really kicked off, uh, with the whole political advertising thing. I mean, Dorsey at Twitter was pretty vocal about this for a while, wasn't he?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought. The announcement from Dorseys Twitter account came on the cusp of Facebooks scheduled third-quarter earnings call...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he totally was. Twitter actually made the first big move, remember? They announced they were halting *all* political advertising on their platform. Dorsey's argument was basically, 'Hey, we don't want to live in a world where tech companies decide what's 100% true.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he totally was. Twitter actually made the first big move, remember? They announced they were halting all political advertising on their platform. Dorsey's argument was basically, 'Hey, we don't want to live in a world where tech companies decide what's one hundred percent true.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I dont think most people want to live in a world where you can only post things that tech companies judge to be 100% true, Zuckerberg said during a Georgetown University speech earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which, I mean, is an interesting take, because then Facebook comes along, and Zuckerberg announces *they're* going to abolish political advertising too, but for a completely different reason.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, I mean, is an interesting take, because then Facebook comes along, and Zuckerberg announces they're going to abolish political advertising too, but for a completely different reason.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dorseys comments took aim at how Zuckerberg has defended Facebooks political ads policy, which allows politicians and political candidates to make false claims in advertisements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Zuckerberg's like, 'Political message reach should be earned, not bought.' It's not about free expression for him, it's about, like, paying to boost reach, which has huge ramifications.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Zuckerberg's like, 'Political message reach should be earned, not bought.' It's not about free expression for him, it's about, like, paying to boost reach, which has huge ramifications.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And he really took a veiled shot at Dorsey, didn't he? Saying it wouldn't be credible to stop people from gaming systems but then allow anyone to say anything if they just pay for an ad. He even added a wink!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he really took a veiled shot at Dorsey, didn't he? Saying it wouldn't be credible to stop people from gaming systems but then allow anyone to say anything if they just pay for an ad. He even added a wink!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dorsey added a less veiled shot to the thread as well, noting it wouldnt be credible to say: Were working hard to stop people from gaming our systems to spread misleading info, buuut if someone pays us to target and force people to see their political ad well ... they can say whatever they want! Then, he added a wink.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That wink was everything, honestly. It just highlighted how deep this rivalry runs. And Zuckerberg basically said Dorsey's whole free speech argument had a 'major gap and flaw.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That wink was everything, honestly. It just highlighted how deep this rivalry runs. And Zuckerberg basically said Dorsey's whole free speech argument had a 'major gap and flaw.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During an appearance at the Twitter News Summit in New York City after Zuckerbergs Georgetown speech, Dorsey said that Zuckerbergs free speech argument had a major gap and flaw in the substance he was getting across.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he went so far as to call it 'revisionist history' in Dorsey's storytelling, which, ouch. That's a pretty strong accusation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he went so far as to call it 'revisionist history' in Dorsey's storytelling, which, ouch. That's a pretty strong accusation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There's some amount of revisionist history in all his storytelling, Dorsey said of Zuckerberg.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Super strong! But Dorsey's fired back too, right? Like, that leaked audio from a Twitter meeting where he basically mocked Facebook's efforts to fix their network's health.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Super strong! But Dorsey's fired back too, right? Like, that leaked audio from a Twitter meeting where he basically mocked Facebook's efforts to fix their network's health.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On October 1, when The Verge published leaked audio from a Facebook company meeting, Zuckerberg mocks Twitter and its efforts to fix the health of their network.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I remember that! He was like, 'Our investment in safety is bigger than the whole revenue of their company!' I mean, that's a pretty direct jab.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I remember that! He was like, 'Our investment in safety is bigger than the whole revenue of their company!' I mean, that's a pretty direct jab.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our investment on safety is bigger than the whole revenue of their company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. And it just shows how fundamentally they disagree on how to manage these massive platforms, especially when it comes to, like, disinformation ahead of a big election.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. And it just shows how fundamentally they disagree on how to manage these massive platforms, especially when it comes to, like, disinformation ahead of a big election.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...both facing pressure to eliminate massive disinformation campaigns on their networks ahead of the 2020 general election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It's not just a philosophical debate, it's also about the practical impact on democracy, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It's not just a philosophical debate, it's also about the practical impact on democracy, really.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And paying to increase the reach of political speech has significant ramifications that todays democratic infrastructure may not be prepared to handle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And it doesn't seem like this spat is going to cool down anytime soon, does it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And it doesn't seem like this spat is going to cool down anytime soon, does it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. I think we're going to keep seeing these two internet moguls at odds for a while.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. I think we're going to keep seeing these two internet moguls at odds for a while.
